Message.Msg: Why do you think shorting is better advice than buying long-dated puts? I understand you think options are a scam, but by this logic, isn't the whole market a scam? Individual investors are losing millions on options plays gone bad. But before they lost just as much on stocks. Even if options didn't exist, big money would still have the advantage and would still exercise a great deal of control over the market at the expense of the individual investor. But there are many things that cannot be predicted and cannot be controlled. In extreme situations big money can no longer control the market. It turns against them. That is when you are going to make money on AMZN going down, and when AMZN crashes you are going to make money whether you are holding puts or short of the underlying. The problem is no one knows exactly when it's going to happen. At the very least you need to know someone's financial situation and risk tolerance before you recommend they short AMZN. Not everyone has the capital to short a stock like this, or to keep shorting it until the known date when it crashes, and shorting exposes one to the possibility of infinite losses. With long-dated puts one's losses are limited to the premiums. If at the end of the contract, the option expires worthless, the buyer still lost more money than anyone who held onto a short position during that length of time. Conceivably at some point the short would have been forced to cover and possibly be pushed out of the market altogether as a result of the loss.

Message.Msg: Are there any good articles dealing with how the limit up limit down rule will actually work in real world situations? Right now it is not clear to me that this rule will make long term options worthless. If there is strong buying or selling pressure in a stock, the stock will make a massive move to the up or downside in the short term. Rules like this cannot stop fear based selling or greed buying. As I understand it this mechanism will just stop massive price movements from taking place too rapidly--five minute periods. This is really just an emergency measure to stop total market collapse instituted at the level of individual securities; it won't stop volatile stocks from being more volatile. In fact if trading is halted due to price collapse in an equity during that time sell orders will continue piling up and will have to be executed when trading resumes. I don't know if all of this is totally correct, but this is understanding based on the information I have read which was released by the SEC. If you can provide reference to any good articles on the subject, I'd like to read them.
